You mislead me by mentioning log without context. In the observability field, log is another thing. You were asking logs of span

Also, you could submit pull request to adjust doc. This doesn't have to do by any specific person, that is how open source community works.

@T-baby, how did you determine that there are no tests for Vert.x 3.8+? There are basic tests for 3.0.x - 3.9.x.

What additionally should be tested and can you produce this issue in a demo repo?

Just trace id is not enough. Like we talked, I still prefer to use collaberate context to do by yourself.
@MikelPan tell us how you set the level please
i is configure agent cofnig logging.level=${SW_LOGGING_LEVEL:INFO},but i java pom file is configure log-back is debug
What do you mean pom file? We don't provide pom file.

skywalking agent is to java Program. i java Program log level is config to debug，but skywalking agent is java agent，log level configure INFO，but in java Program log is diaplay skywalking log，and skywalking log level is debug
It is on the supported list for a long time. Please read document.
Duplicated, it is not supported yet.

It is very hard to understand your words. The way you expressing is quite tricky.
But no matter what your points are,
**We don't output anything to your app logs, besides the gRPC, which has been documented in the FAQ.**

For a trace view, it is easy, same in SkyWalking and Zipkin. 

But from my guessing, you are asking the statistics of the MQ consuming. That is not available in the Zipkin too. So, if you want to talk about that, the only high-performance way is to propagate the sending time(header injecting timestamp) in the extension header, https://github.com/apache/skywalking/blob/master/docs/en/protocols/Skywalking-Cross-Process-Propagation-Headers-Protocol-v3.md#extension-header-item.

If you are going to implement this, we should consider making it optional, such as
- `sw8-x` = `0-mq_send_timestamp` or `-mq_send_timestamp`
- `sw8-x` = `0`

FYI @arugal Would this be a break for the go2sky side if we enhance in this way?

> For a trace view, it is easy, same in SkyWalking and Zipkin.
> 
> But from my guessing, you are asking the statistics of the MQ consuming. That is not available in the Zipkin too. So, if you want to talk about that, the only high-performance way is to propagate the sending time(header injecting timestamp) in the extension header, https://github.com/apache/skywalking/blob/master/docs/en/protocols/Skywalking-Cross-Process-Propagation-Headers-Protocol-v3.md#extension-header-item.
> 
> If you are going to implement this, we should consider making it optional, such as
> 
> * `sw8-x` = `0-mq_send_timestamp` or `-mq_send_timestamp`
> * `sw8-x` = `0`
> 
> FYI @arugal Would this be a break for the go2sky side if we enhance in this way?

The extension header is not currently supported by go2sky.
UT will fail because of #5585.

Do you mean Java agent?
Yes, does java agent have such function?

But ideally, I want to known if we should provide a mechanism at the protocol layer which all agent could follow to let the user disable the header propagation when calling some special thirty party service.

I think today, we don't have such things. As it is hard to tell which is an internal call, the other is for 3rd party, like Dingding. If this really is a block to you, I recommend you add a proxy before calling the dingding server. All HTTP1/2 proxy has the capability to filter or change headers.

Does this make sense to you?

```xml
<configuration>
  <appender name="FILE" class="ch.qos.logback.core.FileAppender">
    <file>myApp.log</file>
    <encoder>
      <pattern>%date %level [%thread] %logger{10} [%file:%line] %msg%n</pattern>
    </encoder>
  </appender>
  <appender name="STDOUT" class="ch.qos.logback.core.ConsoleAppender">
    <encoder>
      <pattern>%msg%n</pattern>
    </encoder>
  </appender>

  <root level="debug">
    <appender-ref ref="FILE" />
    <appender-ref ref="STDOUT" />
  </root>
</configuration>
```
From the above file, you can see that the user used two appenders with different patterns to collect the same log. So I want to know when plugin add error log to span log, should it add all error logs from the two appenders to the span log or just one of them?

ok, I will design a config file in the same level directory of the plugin to filter the log categories that need to be recorded.

The config file may be just like this:
```yaml
logger:log4j/log4j2/logbak #defalut include all 
  package: package name(for exampleorg.apache.skywalking) 
  level: trace/debug/info/error
  parttern: %d{HH:mm:ss.SSS} [%thread] %-5level %logger{36} - %msg%n
```
If the user does not provide a configuration file, the plugin will record all error level logs. Is it ok to design the log plugin?
What kind of format is this layout? It seems like a YAML but it isn't. Please use the standard format, such as yaml/properties/xml

Just like this,is it ok?
```yaml
logger:
  - name: "log4j2"
    package: ["package1","package2","package3"]
    level: "trace"
    pattern: ["Regular expression1","Regular expression2"]
  - name: "logbak"
    package: ["package3","package4"]
    level: "error"
    pattern: ["Regular expression"]
```

Prefer `package: ["package1","package2","package3"]` to the standard array format like this
```yaml
packages:
   - package1
   - package2
   - package3
```

Is this ok?
```yaml
logger:
  - name: "log4j2"
    packages:
      - package1
      - package2
    level: "trace"
    patterns: ["Regular expression1","Regular expression2"]
  - name: "logbak"
    packages:
      - package3
    level: "error"
    patterns: ["Regular expression"]
```
What do you mean by an array of the pattern? What is the case of multiple expressions?

As following logbak config file shows, the config file define two appenders which has different pattern.If user want to colloct all of them , they may need use multiple expressions.Of course,user can use "|" to instead it in one regular expression .
```xml
<configuration>
  <appender name="FILE" class="ch.qos.logback.core.FileAppender">
    <file>myApp.log</file>
    <encoder>
      <pattern>%date %level [%thread] %logger{10} [%file:%line] %msg%n</pattern>
    </encoder>
  </appender>
  <appender name="STDOUT" class="ch.qos.logback.core.ConsoleAppender">
    <encoder>
      <pattern>%msg%n</pattern>
    </encoder>
  </appender>

  <root level="debug">
    <appender-ref ref="FILE" />
    <appender-ref ref="STDOUT" />
  </root>
</configuration>
```
I don't think our way has anything related to the appender. Could you explain why?
My initial idea is to use the `doAppender(E e)` method as an insertion point, and then judge and convert the information according to the requirements of the configuration file.
Because when after exec the "doAppender()",the logs is assembled.
As we have our own config file, why need this? Why don't intercept `log#error` directly?

```java
logger.error("hello world");
```
**unformatted logs:** 
hello world
**formatted logs:**
16:06:09.046 [main] INFO  chapters.configuration.MyApp1 - hello world.
Is it enough to add unformatted logs to the span log?
I think we take the responsibility to format, as we provided file, do you remember why we are discussing about adding our config file? If we use the original format, why need ours?
If there is original API we could call to format the message, it is fine. My point is, we are controlling the format.

ok, I got it. If do so, we should add an attribute named `filter` to filter the logs with regular expression. And the `pattern` to control the formate of the logs.Just like this:
```yaml
logger:
  - name: "log4j2"
    packages:
      - package1
      - package2
    level: "trace"
    pattern: "%date %level [%thread] %logger{10} [%file:%line] %msg%n"
    filter: "Regular expression"
  - name: "logbak"
    packages:
      - package3
    level: "error"
    patterns: "%msg%n"
    filter: "Regular expression"
```
Is it ok?
Please use `expression` to replace `filter`, which seems to make more sense.
